tit.cmt: 表題なので日本語を記載

sen.j: 塚（つか Mound）とはその周囲の地面より、こんもりと丸く盛り上がった場所を指し、具体的には何かが集積、堆積した盛り上がりや、小さな山や丘や古墳などである。
sen.e: A mound means a raised round site situated higher than its surrounding land surface and, specifically, it means an elevation made by a pile of something, small mountain, hill and ancient burial mound.

Tsuka (mound) means a raised round site higher than its surrounding land surface, specifically, it means an elevation made of a pile of something, a small mountain, a hill and an ancient burial mound.

Tsuka (mound) means a raised round site higher than its surrounding land surface, specifically, it means an elevation made of a pile of something, a small mountain, a hill and an ancient burial mound.

sen.j: または、それらの場所や、特別な意味のある場所に、建立された石造や木造などの祠や塔や碑など。
sen.e: More specifically, a mound means hokora (a small shrine), pagoda or monument made of various materials such as stone and wood that were built at these sites or places of particular significance.
Hokora (a small shrine), a pagoda and a monument made of various materials such as stone and wood that were built at these sites or places of particular significance are also a mound.
sen.cmt: 文構成を全体的に見直した
sen.e: Hokora (a small shrine), a pagoda and a monument made of various materials such as stone and wood that were built at these sites or places of particular significance are also a mound.

sen.j: 遺跡としての塚は古墳（こふん Kofun）・墳丘墓（ふんきゅうぼ Tumulus）を参照。
sen.e: For information on mounds in terms of the remains, see Kofun (Ancient Burial Mounds) and Funkyubo (grave mound of tumulus).
For information on mounds in terms of remains, see Kofun (Ancient Burial Mounds) and Funkyubo (grave mound of tumulus).
For information on mounds in terms of remains, see Kofun (Ancient Burial Mounds) and Funkyubo (grave mound of tumulus).

sen.j: その他の人工的な地盤の盛り上がり（Mound）は、土塁・盛土を参照。
sen.e: For the other artificial mounds, see Earthworks and Banks.
For the other artificial mounds, see Earthworks and Banks.
For the other artificial mounds, see Earthworks and Banks.

sen.j: 墓とも解釈されるが、必ずしも遺骸が埋葬されているとは限らず、生物にも限っていないことなどから厳密には区別される。
sen.e: Mounds may be interpreted as tombs but it is not necessarily the remains of creatures, let alone mortal remains for that matter that were buried there, technically, there is a distinction between mounds and tombs.
Mounds may be interpreted as tombs; however in the strict sense of the word, they are not tombs because mortal remains were not necessarily buried and things other than creatures were buried.
sen.cmt: 文の構成全体を見直した
sen.e: Mounds may be interpreted as tombs; however in the strict sense of the word, they are not tombs because mortal remains were not necessarily buried and things other than creatures were buried.

sen.j: 具体的には日本の民間信仰である古神道に、密教や道教の陰陽五行思想などとの習合した様々な信仰において、祈願祈念や感謝や慰霊の記念として建てた碑。
sen.e: Specifically, a mounds is a monument erected to offer prayers, to express gratitude, or as a memorial according to the eclectic teachings of various faiths including the Japanese folk religion Ancient Shinto, esoteric Buddhism and Taoist principle of Yin-Yang and the five elements.

Specifically, the mound is a monument erected to offer prayers, to express gratitude, or as a memory of memoria service, in various faiths constituted through syncretization of the Ancient Shinto (a Japanese folk religion) with esoteric Buddhism and Inyo gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Hsing Idea) of Taoism.
sen.cmt: 文の構成全体を見直した
sen.e: Specifically, the mound is a monument erected to offer prayers, to express gratitude, or as a memory of memoria service, in various faiths constituted through syncretization of the Ancient Shinto (a Japanese folk religion) with esoteric Buddhism and Inyo gogyo shiso (Yin-Yang Wu-Hsing Idea) of Taoism.

sen.j: 荒ぶる神 (神道)にならぬよう祀った碑や感謝や祈願をこめて道具などを祀った碑でもある。
sen.e: It could also be a monument dedicated to appease Araburu Kami (violent god) or dedicated to express appreciation and to offer prayers to various tools used for people's living.

It could also be a monument dedicated to prevent the appearance of Araburu Kami (a violent god in Shinto) or dedicated to express appreciation and to offer prayers to various tools used for people's living.
sen.cmt: 荒ぶる神の部分の説明を変更
sen.e: It could also be a monument dedicated to prevent the appearance of Araburu Kami (a violent god in Shinto) or dedicated to express appreciation and to offer prayers to various tools used for people's living.

sen.j: これらの思いが、江戸時代まで続き昇華した結果として、捕鯨によるクジラの資源としての徹底利用や、鯨塚が日本各地にある理由でもある。
sen.e: Such ways of thinking and attitudes towards the universe as mentioned above which continued and further developed until the Edo Period resulted in the practice of utilizing every inch of captured whales as a resource and Whale Mounds erected in various locations throughout Japan.

Such ways of thinking had been retained through the Edo period and sublimated into an idea, which resulted in the practice of utilizing every inch of captured whales as a resource and a number of mounds for whales erected in various locations throughout Japan.
sen.cmt: 文の構成全体の見直し
sen.e: Such ways of thinking had been retained through the Edo period and sublimated into an idea, which resulted in the practice of utilizing every inch of captured whales as a resource and a number of mounds for whales erected in various locations throughout Japan.

sen.j: また、藁塚や密教塚のように藁屑や焼却灰まで集積した塚などの思想が、藁屑や焼却灰や下肥などを肥料にし流通に乗せ、経済振興と大豆食文化などに繋がる穀倉地や、穀物農耕の隆盛の一端を担ったともいえる。
sen.e: Additionally, it can be said that philosophy behind Wara Zuka (straw mounds) and Mikkyo Zuka (Esoteric Buddhism mounds) that were made with gathered straw bits and ashes, respectively, was responsible for the idea of turning the said materials as well as human waste into fertilizer for distribution whereby playing a role in the economic growth and development of grain belt and grain farming which link to the food culture including soybeans.

Additionally, it can be said that thinking on the mounds of wara zuka (a mound for rice straw) and mikkyo zuka (esoteric Buddhism mound) stacking straw bits and even ashes, caused the conversion of the straw bits, ashes and human wastes into fertilizers and put them into distribution to partly contribute to the development of grain-growing region related to economic growth and food culture of soybeans as well as to the development of grain farming.
sen.cmt: 文の構成全体の見直し。用語を京都プロジェクト用に変更（例. warazuka ）
sen.e: Additionally, it can be said that thinking on the mounds of wara zuka (a mound for rice straw) and mikkyo zuka (esoteric Buddhism mound) stacking straw bits and even ashes, caused the conversion of the straw bits, ashes and human wastes into fertilizers and put them into distribution to partly contribute to the development of grain-growing region related to economic growth and food culture of soybeans as well as to the development of grain farming.

sen.j: 古事記はイザナギとイザナミが、常世（とこよ・黄泉の国）から逃げ帰る時に、鬼神の追っ手を防ぐために、「千引きの岩」（ちびきのいわ）を結界として用いたことと、磐境が結びつき、「結界の神」である「賽の神」（さいのかみ・幸の神）がうまれた。
sen.e: There was an incident described in Kojiki (the Records of Ancient Matters) that, to keep pursuer dispatched by the demon off when returning from Tokoyo (the world of the dead), Izanagi and Izanami used Chibiki no iwa (a huge boulder) as the boundary whereby a boulder became associated with Iwasaka (the area a deity sits) and thus the god of the boundary 'Sai no kami' appeared.

The following story is described in Kojiki (the Records of Ancient Matters) : Izanagi and Izanami used 'Chibiki no iwa' (a huge boulder) as kekkai (barrier) to keep off the pursuers dispatched by the demon when returning from Tokoyo (the world of the dead), and the boulder became associated with iwasaka (the area a deity sits), then the god of the barrier 'Sai no kami' appeared.
sen.cmt: 文の構成全体の見直し
sen.e: The following story is described in Kojiki (the Records of Ancient Matters) : Izanagi and Izanami used 'Chibiki no iwa' (a huge boulder) as kekkai (barrier) to keep off the pursuers dispatched by the demon when returning from Tokoyo (the world of the dead), and the boulder became associated with iwasaka (the area a deity sits), then the god of the barrier 'Sai no kami' appeared.

sen.j: 以来、塚が結界としての意味を持つようになっていき、猿田彦を騙し、ニニギノミコトの道案内をさせ、後に夫婦となったアメノウズメの神話から「衢神」（ちかたのかみ）という「道の神」がうまれた。
sen.e: Mounds subsequently began to have a significance as the boundary, based on the mythology of Amenouzume in which she beguiled Sarudabiko, who later became her husband, into acting as guide for Ninigi-no-mikoto whereby the god of roads 'Chikata no kami' appeared.

Mounds subsequently began to have a significance as the barrier; based on the mythology of Amenouzume in which she beguiled Sarutahiko, who later became her husband, into acting as a guide for Ninigi-no-mikoto, the god of the road 'Chikata no kami' appeared.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を変更。猿田彦の読みを「サルダビコ」から「サルタヒコ」に変更。
sen.e: Mounds subsequently began to have a significance as the barrier; based on the mythology of Amenouzume in which she beguiled Sarutahiko, who later became her husband, into acting as a guide for Ninigi-no-mikoto, the god of the road 'Chikata no kami' appeared.

sen.j: この二つが習合し道祖神信仰となり、石造の塚になっていった。
sen.e: These 2 above-mentioned gods became amalgamated and developed into the Doso-shin (traveler's guardian deity) faith that was to be represented by stone mounds.
These two gods above mentioned became syncretized and developed into the Doso-shin (traveler's guardian deity) faith to become stone mounds.
sen.cmt: These 2 above-mentioned godsをThese two gods above mentionedに変更。習合したをamalgamateからsyncretizedに変更。
sen.e: These two gods above mentioned became syncretized and developed into the Doso-shin (traveler's guardian deity) faith to become stone mounds.

sen.j: この道祖神に、旅の無事を祈願した「手向神」（たむけのかみ）とも習合し、一里塚や峠の塚など集落から離れた場所にも、塚が建立されるようになった。
sen.e: Various mounds such as milestones and mountain-pass mounds dedicated to an eclectic mix of Doso-shin (travelers' guardian deity) and Tamuke no kami (travelers' guardian deity) began to be erected in locations away from villages.

The Doso-shin faith was syncretized with Tamuke no Kami (a travelers' guardian deity) to erect mounds such as ichirizuka (milestones) and mountain-path mounds at locations at a distance from villages.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に変更
sen.e: The Doso-shin faith was syncretized with Tamuke no Kami (a travelers' guardian deity) to erect mounds such as ichirizuka (milestones) and mountain-path mounds at locations at a distance from villages.

sen.j: 後述において「○○塚」という表記がまったく同じでも、その建立された意図や意味（場所も別々）が違うものもあり、様々である。
sen.e: Some of the mounds as described later have been named identically but they vary from one another in terms of the purpose and significance (in addition to the location) of their existence.
Some of the mounds having different purposes and significances (in addition, erected at different locations) have the identical name as described later.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に変更。
sen.e: Some of the mounds having different purposes and significances (in addition, erected at different locations) have the identical name as described later.

sen.j: 例として「姫塚」は古墳の名称である塚と「とある姫」が亡くなったことを祈念した「姫塚」がある。
sen.e: For example, 'Hime Zuka' (princess mound) could be the appellative of ancient burial mounds or may be a mound dedicated to a certain princess in her memory.
For example, there are two kinds of 'Hime Zuka' (princess mound); one is the appellative of ancient burial mounds, the other one is a mound dedicated to a certain princess in her memory.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に変更。
sen.e: For example, there are two kinds of 'Hime Zuka' (princess mound); one is the appellative of ancient burial mounds, the other one is a mound dedicated to a certain princess in her memory.

sen.j: 祭礼
sen.e: Festivals
Festivals
Festivals

sen.j: 古来から日本では、森羅万象に霊魂や命が宿る考えてきた。
sen.e: In Japan, it has been believed that spirit and life reside with everything in the universe since ancient times.
sen.cmt: 「命が宿る考えてきた」は「命が宿ると考えてきた」の誤植だと思われます。
sen.e: In Japan, it has been believed that spirit and life reside with everything in the universe since ancient times.
In Japan, it has been believed that spirit and life reside with everything in the universe since ancient times.

sen.j: これは、文化人類学におけるアニミズム論でもいわれるように、世界中の初期文明において、押並べて自然発生的に生まれた信仰と同じくするものである。
sen.e: This philosophy, as discussed in the Animism doctrine of cultural anthropology, is similar to religions that spontaneously emerged during the times of the primary civilization around the world.
This philosophy, as discussed in the field of animism in cultural anthropology, is similar to religions that spontaneously emerged during the times of the primary civilization around the world.
sen.cmt: 文化人類学におけるアニミズム論をthe field of animism in cultural anthropologyとした.
sen.e: This philosophy, as discussed in the field of animism in cultural anthropology, is similar to religions that spontaneously emerged during the times of the primary civilization around the world.

sen.j: 古神道ともいい、その起源は分かっているだけでも、縄文時代まで遡り、縄文神道ともいわれる。
sen.e: Some say that it was the philosophy of the Ancient Shinto, whereas, other say that it was the Jomon Shinto which, to the best of one's knowledge, goes back to the Jomon Period.
This philosophy is called the Ancient Shinto, the origin of which traces back at least to the Jomon perid, and it is also called the Jomon Shinto.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に見直した。
sen.e: This philosophy is called the Ancient Shinto, the origin of which traces back at least to the Jomon perid, and it is also called the Jomon Shinto.

sen.j: 封建社会を経て近代化してもなお、このような原始宗教ともいわれる世界観を持ち合わせる国は少なく、日本独特に育まれてきた観念からの祭礼でもある。
sen.e: There are a few countries that retain an interpretation of the world based on such a primitive faith even now that the country has modernized following the feudal period and it is a festival originated from the concept that has specifically been nurtured in Japan.

Among modernized countries having undergone feudal perods, only a few countries retain such an interpretation of the world which can be called a primitive faith; it is also a festival originated from the concept that has specifically been nurtured in Japan.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に見直した。
sen.e: Among modernized countries having undergone feudal perods, only a few countries retain such an interpretation of the world which can be called a primitive faith; it is also a festival originated from the concept that has specifically been nurtured in Japan.

sen.j: 奉り・記念
sen.e: Dedicatory and Commemorative Mounds
Dedicatory and Commemorative Mounds
Dedicatory and Commemorative Mounds

sen.j: 高名な人々の足跡や業績に対し、敬意や信望から奉った（たてまつった）塚である。
sen.e: These mounds were dedicated to persons of great distinction to pay homage and respect for their marks and achievements.
These mounds were dedicated to persons of great distinction to pay homage and confidence for their marks and achievements.
sen.cmt: 敬意や信望をhomage and respectからhomage and confidenceに変更。
sen.e: These mounds were dedicated to persons of great distinction to pay homage and confidence for their marks and achievements.

sen.j: 晴明塚
sen.e: Seimei Zuka (Seimei Mounds)
Seimei Zuka (Seimei Mounds)
Seimei Zuka (Seimei Mounds)

sen.j: - 晴明塚とは嵯峨_(京都市)嵐山の晴明神社などにあり、安倍晴明の時代の後世に祈祷師達が安倍晴明を祖師として祈念し、日本各地に建てた塚。
sen.e: - Seimei Mounds were built in various locations in Japan including Seimei-jinja Shrine in Saga Arashiyama (Kyoto City) to offer prayers to their founder ABE no Seimei by oracles of the post-Seimei era.

- Seimei Mounds were built at various locations in Japan including Seimei-jinja Shrine in Saga Arashiyama (Kyoto City) to offer prayers to their founder ABE no Seimei by shamans of the post-Seimei era.
sen.cmt: 祈祷師達をoraclesからshamansに変更。
sen.e: - Seimei Mounds were built at various locations in Japan including Seimei-jinja Shrine in Saga Arashiyama (Kyoto City) to offer prayers to their founder ABE no Seimei by shamans of the post-Seimei era.

sen.j: 芭蕉塚
sen.e: Basho Zuka (Basho Mound)
Basho Zuka (Basho Mound)
Basho Zuka (Basho Mound)

sen.j: - 芭蕉塚とは松尾芭蕉が詠んだ句や立ち寄った日本各地でそれらを記念して立てられた塚。
sen.e: -Basho Mounds are the mounds built in various locations in Japan to commemorate poems written by Basho MATSUO and places that he visited.
-Basho Mounds are the mounds built in various locations in Japan to commemorate poems written by Basho MATSUO and places that he visited.
-Basho Mounds are the mounds built in various locations in Japan to commemorate poems written by Basho MATSUO and places that he visited.

sen.j: 蓑塚（みのつか）
sen.e: Mino Tsuka (Mound for Straw Raincoats)
Mino Tsuka (Mound for Straw Raincoats)
Mino Tsuka (Mound for Straw Raincoats)

sen.j: - 新潟市中央区西堀の善導寺と宗現寺にあり、松尾芭蕉がこの土地に立ち寄ったことを記念して後世に建立された古くなった蓑の道具塚でもある。
sen.e: - Located on the grounds of Zendo-ji Temple and Sogen-ji Temple in Nishibori, Chuo Ward, Niigata Prefecture, they were also dogu zuka for old worn straw raincoats erected later on to commemorate the occasion of Basho Matsuo's visit to this area.

- Located at the grounds of Zendo-ji Temple and Sogen-ji Temple in Nishibori, Chuo Ward, Niigata City, Niigata Prefecture, they are also dogu zuka for old worn straw raincoats erected to commemorate the occasion of Basho Matsuo's visit to this area.
sen.cmt: 新潟市(Niigata City)を追加。they were をthey areに変更。
sen.e: - Located at the grounds of Zendo-ji Temple and Sogen-ji Temple in Nishibori, Chuo Ward, Niigata City, Niigata Prefecture, they are also dogu zuka for old worn straw raincoats erected to commemorate the occasion of Basho Matsuo's visit to this area.

sen.j: なぜ蓑なのかは分かっていないが「海に降る 雨や恋しき 浮き身宿」という句をこの地を訪れた時に詠んだといわれていて「雨」の一文と蓑の関連が示唆される。
sen.e: The reason why they are referred to as Mino Tsuka remains unknown but the reference to 'rain' in a poem said to be written by Basho that reads, 'When rain falling on the sea is getting me soaked, how I long for the warm body of a prostitute' suggested its association with straw raincoats.

The reason why they are referred to as mino tsuka remains unknown, but the word 'rain' in a poem considered to have been written by Basho that reads, 'When rain falling on the sea is getting me soaked, how I long for the warm body of a prostitute' suggests its association with straw raincoats.
sen.cmt: Mino Tsukaを mino tsuka に変更。「詠んだといわれていて」を said to be written by から considered to have been written by に変更。
sen.e: The reason why they are referred to as mino tsuka remains unknown, but the word 'rain' in a poem considered to have been written by Basho that reads, 'When rain falling on the sea is getting me soaked, how I long for the warm body of a prostitute' suggests its association with straw raincoats.

sen.j: 綿弓塚（わたゆみつか）
sen.e: Watayumi Tsuka
Watayumi Tsuka
Watayumi Tsuka

sen.j: - 1684年（貞享元年）に松尾芭蕉が門人の一人である千里の縁（ゆかり）の地、葛城市の竹内で「綿弓や琵琶になぐさむ竹のおく」という句を詠んだ。
sen.e: - In 1684, Basho MATSUO wrote a poem that reads, 'The sound of watayumi bow beating cotton is beautiful like that of Japanese lute buoying my spirit' in Takenouchi, Katsuragi City that was associated with his pupil Senri.

- In 1684, Basho MATSUO wrote a poem that reads, 'The sound of watayumi bow beating cotton is beautiful like that of Japanese lute buoying my spirit' at Takenouchi, Katsuragi City that was associated with one of his pupils Senri.
sen.cmt: 門人の一人という表現にするためhis pupilをone of his pupilsに変更。
sen.e: - In 1684, Basho MATSUO wrote a poem that reads, 'The sound of watayumi bow beating cotton is beautiful like that of Japanese lute buoying my spirit' at Takenouchi, Katsuragi City that was associated with one of his pupils Senri.

sen.j: これを記念して千里の屋敷跡の興善庵に1809年（文化6年）に句碑が建てられた。
sen.e: In 1809, a poem monument was erected to commemorate the above event within the grounds of Kozen-an which used be Senri's residence.
In 1809, a poem monument was erected to commemorate the above event within the ground of Kozen-an which was Senri's residence.
sen.cmt: which used beをwhich wasに変更。
sen.e: In 1809, a poem monument was erected to commemorate the above event within the ground of Kozen-an which was Senri's residence.

sen.j: 法華塚
sen.e: Hokke Zuka
Hokke Zuka
Hokke Zuka

sen.j: - 法華塚とは法華経塚ともいい日蓮上人が伊豆へ流刑されていた時に鎌倉と生誕地である安房国を思い安寧と仏教の広まりを祈念し、写経した法華経を埋めた塚。
sen.e: - Hokke Zuka is also referred to as Hokke-kyo Zuka that is a mound in which Nichiren Shonin (the Venerable Nichiren) buried a copy of the Lotus Sutra that he transcribed thinking of Kamakura and his birthplace Awa Province and praying for peace and propagation of Buddhism during his exile in Izu Province.

- Hokke zuka is also referred to as Hokke-kyo zuka that is a mound in which Nichiren shonin (the Venerable Nichiren) buried a copy of the Lotus Sutra that he transcribed thinking of Kamakura and his birthplace Awa Province and praying for peace and propagation of Buddhism during his exile in Izu Province.
sen.cmt: Hokke Zuka, Hokke-kyo ZukaのZukaを共にzukaに変更。Shoninをshoninに変更。
sen.e: - Hokke zuka is also referred to as Hokke-kyo zuka that is a mound in which Nichiren shonin (the Venerable Nichiren) buried a copy of the Lotus Sutra that he transcribed thinking of Kamakura and his birthplace Awa Province and praying for peace and propagation of Buddhism during his exile in Izu Province.

sen.j: 祭り・慰霊
sen.e: Dedicatory and Memorial
Dedicatory and Memorial
Dedicatory and Memorial

sen.j: 古神道や神道において、神霊は二つ（四魂という考えもある）の様相を持ち荒御魂（あらみたま）・和御魂（にぎみたま）ともいわれる。
sen.e: In the Ancient Shinto and Shinto teachings, it is considered that there are 2 aspects (or 4 spirits according to another philosophy) of a divine spirit known as Aramitama (wrathful divine spirit) and Nigimitama (peaceful divine spirit).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In the Ancient Shinto and Shinto teachings, it is considered that there are two aspects (or four spirits according to another philosophy) of a divine spirit known as Aramitama (wrathful divine spirit) and Nigimitama (peaceful divine spirit).

In the Ancient Shinto and Shinto teachings, it is considered that there are two aspects (or four spirits according to another philosophy) of a divine spirit known as Aramitama (wrathful divine spirit) and Nigimitama (peaceful divine spirit).

sen.j: 荒れ狂う時と和やかな落ち着いた時があり、禍と福をもたらすと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that there are times when the divine spirit is violent and there are other times when it is quiet and calm, representing evils and blessings.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is considered that there are times when the divine spirit is violent and there are other times when it is quiet and calm, representing evils and blessings, respectively.
It is considered that there are times when the divine spirit is violent and there are other times when it is quiet and calm, representing evils and blessings, respectively.

sen.j: また祖霊信仰や自然崇拝から、無念を伴って亡くなった生命は荒御魂になり、禍をもたらすこともあると考えていたので、その御霊代（みたましろ・依り代）として塚を建立し慰霊して来た歴史がある。
sen.e: Additionally, according to the teachings of ancestor and nature worship, since it was believed that a life ended in bitter disappointment would turn into a wrathful spirit which might bring evils to this world, history shows that a mound was erected as an object to be honored in place of a person's soul (divine spirit) for the repose of their spirit.

Additionally, based on the teachings of ancestor and nature worship, since it was believed that a life ended in bitter disappointment would turn into a wrathful spirit which might bring evils to this world, history shows that a mound was erected as an object to be honored in place of a person's soul (divine spirit) for the repose of his or her spirit.
sen.cmt: according to を based on に変更。their spirit を his or her spirit に変更。
sen.e: Additionally, based on the teachings of ancestor and nature worship, since it was believed that a life ended in bitter disappointment would turn into a wrathful spirit which might bring evils to this world, history shows that a mound was erected as an object to be honored in place of a person's soul (divine spirit) for the repose of his or her spirit.

sen.j: 「祭り」の本来の漢字の意味は慰霊である。
sen.e: The original definition of kanji representing 'festival' is memorial.
The original definition of kanji representing 'festival' is a memorial service.
sen.cmt: memorial を a memorial service に変更。
sen.e: The original definition of kanji representing 'festival' is a memorial service.

sen.j: 首塚
sen.e: Kubi-zuka (Monument of Severed Heads)
Kubi-zuka (Mound for Severed Head)
sen.cmt: Monument of Severed Heads を Mound for Severed Head に変更。
sen.e: Kubi-zuka (Mound for Severed Head)

sen.j: - 首塚とは戦場や戦いにおいて裁かれたり亡くなった人々の首を埋葬し弔いや荒ぶる神にならないよう祀った塚。
sen.e: - Kubi zuka is a burial place of heads of persons beheaded during the war or by the judgment of trial after the war for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.
- Kubi-zuka is a burial place of heads of persons beheaded during the war or by the judgment of trial after the war for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.
sen.cmt: Kubi zuka を タイトルに合わせてKubi-zuka に変更。
sen.e: - Kubi-zuka is a burial place of heads of persons beheaded during the war or by the judgment of trial after the war for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.

sen.j: 戦場では敵味方の区別無く建立された物もある。
sen.e: In battle fields, there were some kubi zuka dedicated to anyone, friend and foe alike.
In some battle fields, the kubi-zuka was erected so as to enshrine friends and foes alike.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に変更。
sen.e: In some battle fields, the kubi-zuka was erected so as to enshrine friends and foes alike.

sen.j: 胴塚
sen.e: Dozuka (Monument of Headless Bodies)
Dozuka (Mound for Severed Torso)
Dozuka (Mound for Severed Torso)

sen.j: - 胴塚とは戦場や戦いにおいて亡くなった人々の胴体の埋葬地である。
sen.e: - Do zuka is a burial place of headless bodies of persons perished in the battle field or killed in action.
- Dozuka is a burial place of headless bodies of persons perished in the battle field or killed in action.
sen.cmt: Do zuka を Dozuka に変更。
sen.e: - Dozuka is a burial place of headless bodies of persons perished in the battle field or killed in action.

sen.j: それらの胴体を集めて埋葬し弔いや荒ぶる神にならないよう祀った塚。
sen.e: Those headless bodies were collected and buried under do zuka for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.
Those headless bodies were collected and buried in the dozuka for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.
sen.cmt: under do zuka を in the dozuka に変更。
sen.e: Those headless bodies were collected and buried in the dozuka for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.

sen.j: 刀塚
sen.e: Nata Zuka (Monument of Weapons)
Katana zuka (Mound for Weapons)
sen.cmt: 刀塚の読みを「かたなづか」とした。
sen.e: Katana zuka (Mound for Weapons)

sen.j: - 刀塚とは戦場や戦いにおいて亡くなった人々の武具を集めて埋葬し弔い祀った塚。
sen.e: - Nata Zuka is dedicated to weapons of persons perished in battle fields or killed in action that were collected and buried.
- Katana zuka is dedicated to weapons of the people perished in battle fields or killed in action that were collected and buried.
sen.cmt: Nata Zuka を Katana zuka に変更。 persons を the people に変更。
sen.e: - Katana zuka is dedicated to weapons of the people perished in battle fields or killed in action that were collected and buried.

sen.j: 戦場跡での刀泥棒などから遺品を守ったという説もある。
sen.e: There is another explanation that these mounds were built to protect personal effects of the dead from sword thieves.
There is another explanation that these mounds were built to protect personal effects of the dead from sword thieves at a battle field when the battle was over.
sen.cmt: 「戦場跡での」の部分の訳を追加。
sen.e: There is another explanation that these mounds were built to protect personal effects of the dead from sword thieves at a battle field when the battle was over.

sen.j: 蒙古塚
sen.e: Mounds of Mongol Warriors
Mokozuka (Tumulus for Mongol Warriors)
Mokozuka (Tumulus for Mongol Warriors)

sen.j: - 蒙古塚とは蒙古襲来のときに戦場や戦いにおいて亡くなった蒙古の人々を埋葬し弔いや荒ぶる神にならないよう祀った塚。
sen.e: - Mounds of Mongol Warriors are the mounds under which Mongolians perished in battle fields or killed in action during the Mongolian invasion were buried for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.

- Mokozuka is a mound at which Mongolians perished in battle fields or killed in action during the Mongolian invasion were buried for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.
sen.cmt: 主語を Mounds of Mongol Warriors から Mokozuka に変更。
sen.e: - Mokozuka is a mound at which Mongolians perished in battle fields or killed in action during the Mongolian invasion were buried for the repose of their souls so that they would not become violent gods.

sen.j: 鯨塚
sen.e: Kujira Zuka (Whale Monument)
Kujira Zuka (Mound for Whales)
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に変更。
sen.e: Kujira Zuka (Mound for Whales)

sen.j: - 鯨塚とは流れ鯨や寄り鯨などを受動的に捕鯨した地域や捕鯨を生業にしている地域において鯨に感謝し弔い祀った塚。
sen.e: - Whale mounds were erected in various regions where they capture beached whales and where they practice whaling in appreciation for and in memory of whales.

- Kujirazuka (mounds for whales) were erected in various regions where people effortlessly captured whales such as beached whales and where people practiced whaling, in appreciation for and in memory of whales.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に見直した。
sen.e: - Kujirazuka (mounds for whales) were erected in various regions where people effortlessly captured whales such as beached whales and where people practiced whaling, in appreciation for and in memory of whales.

sen.j: 類似するものとして鯨墓、鯨碑、鯨供養塔などが日本各地に存在する。
sen.e: There are other similar whale-related monuments including Kujira baka (graves of whales), Kujira-hi (monuments for whales) and Kujira-kuyoto (pagodas erected in memory of whales) in various regions of in Japan.
Similar whale-related mounds such as Kujira-baka (graves of whales), Kujira-hi (monuments for whales) and Kujira-kuyoto (pagodas erected in memory of whales) can be seen across Japan.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に見直した。
sen.e: Similar whale-related mounds such as Kujira-baka (graves of whales), Kujira-hi (monuments for whales) and Kujira-kuyoto (pagodas erected in memory of whales) can be seen across Japan.

sen.j: 詳しくは捕鯨文化を参照。
sen.e: See Whaling Culture for details.
See Whaling Culture for details.
See Whaling Culture for details.

sen.j: 祀り・感謝
sen.e: Dedicatory and Thanksgiving
Dedication and Thanksgiving
sen.cmt: Dedicatory を名詞の Dedication に変更。
sen.e: Dedication and Thanksgiving

sen.j: 室町時代の頃から軽工業の発達により、都市部を中心に、消費社会の傾向が出始めていた。
sen.e: Around the Muromachi Period, with development of light manufacturing, consumer society started to become a trend in and around major cities.
Around the Muromachi period, with development of light manufacturing, consumer society started to become a trend in and around major cities.
sen.cmt: the Muromachi Period を the Muromachi periodに変更。
sen.e: Around the Muromachi period, with development of light manufacturing, consumer society started to become a trend in and around major cities.

sen.j: それまでは、自然崇拝や祖霊崇拝であった観念が、家畜や器物（生活の道具）にまで及び、「もの」を粗末にしないようにとの思いから、九十九神などの神霊の観念が生まれ、江戸時代まで引き継がれた。
sen.e: The philosophy of ancestor and nature worship up to the point in time began to extend to value livestock and properties (tools used in daily life) and the idea of divine spirits such as Tsukumogami (the divine spirit that resides in old tools or creatures) was developed which was carried on until the Edo Period.

The philosophy which had been for ancestor worship and nature worship, began to cover livestock and properties (tools used in daily life), and in order to save on things, the idea of divine spirits such as Tsukumogami (the divine spirit that resides in old tools or creatures) was developed, which was inherited down to the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 文の構成全体を見直した。
sen.e: The philosophy which had been for ancestor worship and nature worship, began to cover livestock and properties (tools used in daily life), and in order to save on things, the idea of divine spirits such as Tsukumogami (the divine spirit that resides in old tools or creatures) was developed, which was inherited down to the Edo period.

sen.j: そして、昨今の研究によれば、江戸時代は世界で例を見ない資源還元（リサイクル）社会であったといわれている。
sen.e: According to the recent studies, it is said that, during the Edo Period, Japan was an unprecedented recycling-oriented society in the world.
According to the recent studies, during the Edo period, Japan was an unprecedented recycling-oriented society in the world.
sen.cmt: it is said that は不要と判断し除去
sen.e: According to the recent studies, during the Edo period, Japan was an unprecedented recycling-oriented society in the world.

sen.j: 道具塚
sen.e: Dogu Zuka (Monument of Tools)
Dogu Zuka
sen.cmt: 題目なので単にDogu Zukaとした
sen.e: Dogu Zuka

sen.j: - 道具塚とは普段使っている生活道具が使用できない状態になったとき感謝を込めて埋めたり、様々な職業の道具を埋め感謝しその職の技術の向上を祈願して建てられた塚。
sen.e: - Dogu Zuka is a mound erected to bury old worn tools used in daily life and tools used in various professions in appreciation of their many years of service as well as to pray for improving skills in one's work.

- Dogu zuka (grave for tool) is a mound erected to bury old worn tools used in daily life and tools used in various professions in appreciation of their many years of service as well as to pray for improving skills in one's work.
sen.cmt: 主語を Dogu Zuka から Dogu zuka (grave for tool) に変更。
sen.e: - Dogu zuka (grave for tool) is a mound erected to bury old worn tools used in daily life and tools used in various professions in appreciation of their many years of service as well as to pray for improving skills in one's work.

sen.j: 庖丁塚（包丁塚）
sen.e: Hocho Zuka (Monument of Knives)
Hocho-zuka (Mound for kitchen knives)
Hocho-zuka (Mound for kitchen knives)

sen.j: - 庖丁塚とは使い古されたり使えなくなってしまった包丁に感謝を込めて埋めたり、包丁捌きの技術の向上祈願して建てられた塚。
sen.e: - Hocho Zuka was erected to bury old worn knives to express appreciation for many years of service and to pray for improving skills in using knives for cooking.
- Hocho-zuka was erected to bury old worn knives to express appreciation for many years of service and to pray for improving skills in using knives for cooking.
sen.cmt: Hocho Zuka を Hocho-zuka に変更。
sen.e: - Hocho-zuka was erected to bury old worn knives to express appreciation for many years of service and to pray for improving skills in using knives for cooking.

sen.j: または、庖丁はふるくは刀を転用して作られており魂を入れなければ使用できなかったその入魂のための塚。
sen.e: In old days, cooking knives were made from recycled swords and since those cooking knives had to be charged with spirit before using, dogu zuka was also erected for this purpose.
In old days, knives for cooking were made from recycled swords and those knives had to be charged with spirit before using, then the dogu-zuka was erected for the purpose of charging.
sen.cmt: 文の構成を全体的に見直した。
sen.e: In old days, knives for cooking were made from recycled swords and those knives had to be charged with spirit before using, then the dogu-zuka was erected for the purpose of charging.

sen.j: 人形塚
sen.e: Ningyo Zuka (Monument of Dolls)
Ningyo-zuka (Grave for Dolls)
sen.cmt: Ningyo zuka を Ningyo-zukaに変更。訳も変更。
sen.e: Ningyo-zuka (Grave for Dolls)

sen.j: - 人形塚とは古くなったり飾ることが出来なくなった人形を感謝して埋めたり、身代わりとして厄を落とす祈願をした人形を埋めた塚。
sen.e: - Ningyo-zuka (doll tomb) is a mound where old worn dolls were buried in appreciation for the enjoyment that they offered to their owners and also where dolls are buried as substitutes for people in hope to protect them from evils.

- Ningyo-zuka is a mound where old worn dolls were buried in appreciation for the enjoyment that they offered to their owners and also where dolls are buried as substitutes for people in hope to protect them from evils.
sen.cmt: 主語を Ningyo-zuka に変更。
sen.e: - Ningyo-zuka is a mound where old worn dolls were buried in appreciation for the enjoyment that they offered to their owners and also where dolls are buried as substitutes for people in hope to protect them from evils.

sen.j: 古神道の世界観では、現実世界としての現世（うつしよ）と神域や神の国や死後の世界としての常世（とこよ）・（幽世「かくりよ」とも）に別れている。
sen.e: According to the Ancient Shinto, the world is divided into 2 parts including Utsushiyo (the actural world) as reality and Tokoyo (also known as Kakuriyo (the perpetual country)) as the sacred area, country of gods or afterworld.

According to the world view of the Ancient Shinto, the world is divided into two parts; one is Utsushiyo (the actural world), the other is Tokoyo or Kakuryo (the sacred area, the country of gods, and the afterworld).
sen.cmt: 2を two に変更。その他全体の構成を見直した。
sen.e: According to the world view of the Ancient Shinto, the world is divided into two parts; one is Utsushiyo (the actural world), the other is Tokoyo or Kakuryo (the sacred area, the country of gods, and the afterworld).

sen.j: 神奈備（かむなび）や磐境（いわさか）や神籬（ひもろぎ）などは、その神域との端境であると考えられ、結界としての注連縄が張られ、時には禁足地ともなった。
sen.e: Places such as Kannabi (a place such as a mountain or forest where the divine spirit resides, Iwasaka (the area a deity sits) and Himorogi (a temporarily erected altar used as a place of worship) were considered to be borders between the actual world and the sacred area whereby these places were marked with sacred ropes as barriers and, in some cases, were forbidden to enter.

Places such as Kannabi (a place such as a mountain or forest where the divine spirit resides), Iwasaka (the area a deity sits) and Himorogi (a temporarily erected altar used as a place of worship) were considered to be borders between the actual world and the sacred area whereby these places were marked with sacred ropes as barriers and, in some cases, became kinsokuchi (a tabooed land).

Places such as Kannabi (a place such as a mountain or forest where the divine spirit resides), Iwasaka (the area a deity sits) and Himorogi (a temporarily erected altar used as a place of worship) were considered to be borders between the actual world and the sacred area whereby these places were marked with sacred ropes as barriers and, in some cases, became kinsokuchi (a tabooed land).

sen.j: 場所だけでなく、逢魔時や丑三つ時のように、一日の時刻にもその神域へ誘う、端境があると考えられた。
sen.e: In addition to places, it was considered that certain hours of the day such as Omagadoki (twilight hour) and Ushimitsudoki (the dead of night) served as boundaries to the sacred area.
In addition to places, certain hours of the day such as Omagadoki (twilight hour) and Ushimitsudoki (the dead of night) were thought to serve as boundaries to the sacred area.
sen.cmt: it is considered that を除去して文を構成。
sen.e: In addition to places, certain hours of the day such as Omagadoki (twilight hour) and Ushimitsudoki (the dead of night) were thought to serve as boundaries to the sacred area.

sen.j: これらが時代を経るにしたがい、道の形状の特徴的な峰や峠や坂や、時には橋や門や村境や町境などの集落の境界や、道の交差する辻なども、その神域との端境と考えられた。
sen.e: Over the years, other places such as ridges, mountain passes and slopes in addition to bridges, gates, borders of settlements such as a boundary between 2 villages or 2 towns and intersections where the shape of roads is distinct were also considered the border between the real world and the sacred land.

As the time passed, the following were also considered the border between the real world and the sacred land: ridges, mountain paths and slopes whose shapes of the roads were unique; and in some case, bridges, gates, borders of settlements such as villages and towns, and intersections of roads.
sen.cmt: 文全体の構成の見直し
sen.e: As the time passed, the following were also considered the border between the real world and the sacred land: ridges, mountain paths and slopes whose shapes of the roads were unique; and in some case, bridges, gates, borders of settlements such as villages and towns, and intersections of roads.

sen.j: 道標
sen.e: Signposts
Michishirube (Signposts)
sen.cmt: 表題を Michishirube とした。
sen.e: Michishirube (Signposts)

sen.j: もともとは、「道に迷わないよう」にと作られた道標（みちしるべ）でもあるが、「集落に禍が及ばないよう」にとの思いからの結界でもある。
sen.e: Signposts were originally erected to help travelers stay oriented but were also the boundaries to keep evils out of the village.
Michishirube (signposts) were originally erected to help travelers stay oriented but were also the boundaries to keep evils out of the village.
Michishirube (signposts) were originally erected to help travelers stay oriented but were also the boundaries to keep evils out of the village.

sen.j: 同時に、旅や道すがらの安全を願って建立された塚や、それに類する石造りの像が、今日でも信仰され路傍にひっそりと佇んでいる。
sen.e: There are other mounds and stone statues, having the similar significance to the mounds, erected to wish travelers safe trip are still standing on the roadside and people continue to have faith in them today.
Other types of mounds and stone statues, erected in the past to wish travelers' safe trips, are standing inconspicuously on roadsides today and people still have faith in them.
sen.cmt: 文全体の構成の見直し
sen.e: Other types of mounds and stone statues, erected in the past to wish travelers' safe trips, are standing inconspicuously on roadsides today and people still have faith in them.

sen.j: 道祖神
sen.e: Doso-Shin (Traveler's Guardian Deity)
Doso-shin (Traveler's Guardian Deity)
Doso-shin (Traveler's Guardian Deity)

sen.j: - 道祖神を参照。
sen.e: - See Doso-shin.
- See Doso-shin.
- See Doso-shin.

Jizo
Jizo

sen.e: - See Jizo.
- See Jizo.
- See Jizo.

sen.e: Koshin Zuka
Koshin Zuka
Koshin Zuka

sen.j: - 庚申塚を参照。
sen.e: - See Koshin Zuka.
- See Koshin Zuka.
- See Koshin Zuka.

sen.j: 一里塚
sen.e: Ichiri Zuka (Milestone)
Ichiri Zuka (Milestone)
Ichiri Zuka (Milestone)

sen.j: - 一里塚を参照。
sen.e: - See Ichiri Zuka.
- See Ichiri Zuka.
- See Ichiri Zuka.

sen.j: 祠
sen.e: Hokora (Small Shrine)
Hokora (Small Shrine)
Hokora (Small Shrine)

sen.j: - 祠を参照。
sen.e: - See Hokora.
- See Hokora.
- See Hokora.

sen.j: 権利と紛争
sen.e: Rights and Conflicts
Rights and Conflicts
Rights and Conflicts

sen.j: 入山権や山の帰属や村境や町境をめぐって紛争があり、人々の無念の思いや被害があったことや、その場所がいわゆる神域などの神聖な場所であったことから、そこに宿る神や紛争で命を落としたものに対して、祭った塚が日本各地に存在する。
sen.e: In various locations in Japan, mounds were erected for the repose of the spirits of people, who died subsequent to a conflict over the claim on or ownership of a mountain, boundary of village or town that left them with bitter disappointment or damages, or to dedicate to the god who resides in the particular location designated as a sacred place such as the Shinto shrine precincts.

There were conflicts in various locations in Japan over the claim on or ownership of a mountain, or boundaries of villages or towns, and those conflicts consequently left the people involved with bitter disappointment or damage, and in addition those locations were sacred places such as the Shinto shrine precincts; then mounds were erected to shrine the god residing there and the people who died in the conflicts.
sen.cmt: 文全体の構成の見直し
sen.e: There were conflicts in various locations in Japan over the claim on or ownership of a mountain, or boundaries of villages or towns, and those conflicts consequently left the people involved with bitter disappointment or damage, and in addition those locations were sacred places such as the Shinto shrine precincts; then mounds were erected to shrine the god residing there and the people who died in the conflicts.

sen.j: 鉄火塚
sen.e: Tekka Zuka (Remains of Courts)
Tekka Zuka (Remains of Courts)
Tekka Zuka (Remains of Courts)

sen.j: - 鉄火塚とは地境の紛争の審理として、鉄火の裁判や火起請といわれる迷信のような判定が、「お上」によって行われた。
sen.e: - Tekka Zuka is a place where, back in old days, the 'authority' conducted superstition-like trials on conflicts over the borderline of property referred to as Tekka Saiban (literally the 'red-hot iron trial' whereby one grabbed a red-hot iron bar to make a judgment on the right or wrong of the issue of contention by the appearance of the burn on the hand) and Higisho (to have one grab a piece of red-hot iron to ascertain the truth depending on whether that person can keep the iron piece in his/her hand).

- Tekka Zuka is a place where, back in old days, the 'authority' conducted superstition-like trials on conflicts over the borderline of property referred to as Tekka Saiban (literally the 'red-hot iron trial' whereby one grabbed a red-hot iron bar to make a judgment on the right or wrong of the issue of contention by the appearance of the burn on the hand) and Higisho (to have one grab a piece of red-hot iron to ascertain the truth depending on whether that person can keep the iron piece in his/her hand).

Tekka Zuka is a mound on which the authorities would conduct superstition-based trials to resolve boundary disputes; such trials included the Tekka Saiban (literally the 'red-hot iron trial,' which involved the concerned parties taking hold of a red-hot iron bar to enable a judgment to be made on the issue in question based on whether a burn appeared on their hands) and Higisho (a trial which involved the concerned parties taking hold of a piece of red-hot iron to enable the truth of the matter to be ascertained based upon whether they were able to continue holding the iron piece in their hands).
sen.cmt: 原文に合わせて訳文を修正

sen.j: 神奈川県の横浜市青葉区 (横浜市)鉄町や茨城県筑波谷和原村大字宮土などにある。
sen.e: There were Tekka Zuka in the areas including Kurogane Cho, Aoba Ward, Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture and Oaza Miyado, Yarawa Mura, Tsukuba County, Ibaraki Prefecture.
There were Tekka Zuka in the areas including Kurogane Cho, Aoba Ward, Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture and Oaza Miyado, Yarawa Mura, Tsukuba County, Ibaraki Prefecture.
There were Tekka Zuka in the areas including Kurogane Cho, Aoba Ward, Yokohama City, Kanagawa Prefecture and Oaza Miyado, Yarawa Mura, Tsukuba County, Ibaraki Prefecture.

sen.j: 人や動物の集積
sen.e: Congregated People or Animals
Gathering of People or Animals
Gathering of People or Animals

sen.j: 基本的には、何かが集まった状態で、人や生き物によって築かれる小山も、塚といった。
sen.e: It is basically a condition that some things are gathered and a small pile made by people or creatures was also referred to as a mound.
A small rise made of a pile of something and built by people or creatures was basically also referred to as a mound.
sen.cmt: 文全体の構成の見直し
sen.e: A small rise made of a pile of something and built by people or creatures was basically also referred to as a mound.

sen.j: 水塚も見方を変えれば、緊急時のための食料を集積した貯蔵庫であるし、密教塚も宗教的な意味合いもあるが、貝塚と同様に残滓の集積でもある。
sen.e: From a different perspective, Mizuka was a stockroom for food in times of emergency and while there were some religious implications with Mikkyo Zuka, it was, nonetheless, an accumulation of residues much like Kai Zuka.

Mizu-zuka (a mound used as a shelter) was a stockroom for food in times of emergency from a different perspective, and mikkyo-zuka (mound of esoteric Buddhism) was basically an accumulation of residues much like kai-zuka although it has some religious implication.
sen.cmt: 文全体の構成の見直し
sen.e: Mizu-zuka (a mound used as a shelter) was a stockroom for food in times of emergency from a different perspective, and mikkyo-zuka (mound of esoteric Buddhism) was basically an accumulation of residues much like kai-zuka although it has some religious implication.

sen.j: 残滓
sen.e: Residuary Mounds
Zanshi (Remnant)
Zanshi (Remnant)

sen.j: 貝塚
sen.e: Shell Mounds
Kai-zuka (Shell Mounds)
Kai-zuka (Shell Mounds)

sen.j: - 古い時代の遺跡としても有名で世界各地の海浜部でみられ文字通り、貝を中心とした食物残滓が堆積したものである。
sen.e: - Being well known as the remains of ancient times, shell mounds literally are piles of food waste consisting chiefly of the shells which are seen in various locations throughout the world.
- Being well known as the remains of ancient times, shell mounds literally are piles of food waste consisting chiefly of shells, which are seen in coastal areas throughout the world.
sen.cmt: various locations をcoastal areas に変更。
sen.e: - Being well known as the remains of ancient times, shell mounds literally are piles of food waste consisting chiefly of shells, which are seen in coastal areas throughout the world.

sen.j: 詳しくは「貝塚」を参照。
sen.e: See 'Shell Mounds' for details.
See 'Shell Mounds' for details.
See 'Shell Mounds' for details.

sen.j: 藁塚
sen.e: Wara Zuka (Straw Mounds)
Wara Zuka (a mound for rice straw)
sen.cmt: 京都プロジェクト用語を採用
sen.e: Wara Zuka (a mound for rice straw)

sen.j: - ワラ塚とは他に藁ぐろ、藁小積などとも呼ばれる。
sen.e: - A straw mound is also referred to as waraguro and warakozumi in Japan.
- Wara-zuka is also referred to as wara-guro or wara-kozumi.
- Wara-zuka is also referred to as wara-guro or wara-kozumi.

sen.j: 米の収穫が終え、残った稲藁を利用するため集積し保存した状態。
sen.e: It refers to the condition that, after harvesting rice, the remaining straws scattered in rice paddies have been collected and kept in piles to be subsequently used for various purposes.
It refers to the condition that, after harvesting rice, the remaining rice straws have been collected and kept in piles to be used for various purposes.
sen.cmt: the remaining straws scattered in rice paddies をthe remaining rice straws に変更。
sen.e: It refers to the condition that, after harvesting rice, the remaining rice straws have been collected and kept in piles to be used for various purposes.

sen.j: ちなみに利用の例としては注連縄、草鞋、納豆床、スサ、畳床、米俵、飼料、肥料など多岐に渡る。
sen.e: There are various examples of how the straws are used including Shimenawa ropes (sacred straw ropes), straw sandals, natto (fermented soy bean) wrapping, filler for plaster material, tatami mats, straw rice bales, feed and fertilizers.

There are various examples of usage of rice straws, such as shimenawa (sacred rice straw ropes), straw sandals, natto (fermented soy bean) wrapping, filler material, tatami mats, straw rice bags, feed and fertilizers.
sen.cmt: 文の構成、用語の見直し
sen.e: There are various examples of usage of rice straws, such as shimenawa (sacred rice straw ropes), straw sandals, natto (fermented soy bean) wrapping, filler material, tatami mats, straw rice bags, feed and fertilizers.

sen.j: 草鞋塚
sen.e: Zori Zuka (Zori Mounds)
Zori Zuka (Zori Mounds)
Zori Zuka (Zori Mounds)

sen.j: - ゾウリ塚とは稲藁の二次利用であり人、ウシ、ウマ（明治以前は蹄鉄ではなかった）の履いていた草鞋を肥料にするため集積し保存した状態。
sen.e: - A zori mound is a pile of old straw sandals worn by people, cattle and horses (as there were no horseshoes prior to the Meiji Era) to make fertilizer for secondary use of straw.
- A zori mound is a pile of old straw sandals worn by people, cattle and horses (as there were no horseshoes prior to the Meiji era) to make fertilizer for secondary use of straw.
- A zori mound is a pile of old straw sandals worn by people, cattle and horses (as there were no horseshoes prior to the Meiji era) to make fertilizer for secondary use of straw.

sen.j: 密教塚
sen.e: Mikkyo Zuka
Mikkyo Zuka (Mound of Esoteric Buddhism)
Mikkyo Zuka (Mound of Esoteric Buddhism)

sen.j: - 密教塚とは疫病が流行った時に家や家財道具をすべて燃やして他の地へ移り住むということが、古くから行われていた。
sen.e: - A Mikkyo zuka originated from an old practice that, when an epidemic broke out, people moved to another location after burning their houses and belongings.
- In the past, when an epidemic broke out, people used to move to another place after burning their houses and belongings.
sen.cmt: 文全体の構成の見直し
sen.e: - In the past, when an epidemic broke out, people used to move to another place after burning their houses and belongings.

sen.j: そのことを祈念し燃え残った灰を集めて埋めた場所とされる。
sen.e: A Mikkyo-zuka mound is believed to the site where the ashes of houses and belongings of those people were collected and buried in hope of the end of the epidemic.
The mikkyo-zuka is believed to have been the site where the ashes of houses and belongings of those people were collected and buried in hope of the cease of the epidemic.
sen.cmt: 時制の調整。endの代わりにceaseを使用。
sen.e: The mikkyo-zuka is believed to have been the site where the ashes of houses and belongings of those people were collected and buried in hope of the cease of the epidemic.

sen.j: 食料貯蔵
sen.e: Food Storage Mounds
Food Storage
sen.cmt: 原文に忠実にFood Storageとした
sen.e: Food Storage

sen.j: 水塚
sen.e: Mizuka
Mizu-zuka (a mound used as a shelter)
Mizu-zuka (a mound used as a shelter)

sen.j: - 水塚とは群馬県地方にみられる水害のときの避難施設であり、盛り土の上に木造二階建ての搭状の建物で１階が味噌や食料の貯蔵と家財道具の一時保管場所で2階が居住空間となっている。
sen.e: - The main floor was the storage for miso (soybean paste) and other food in addition to being a temporary store area for household goods, whereas, the second floor was used as a living quarter.

- The mizu-zuka was a shelter in a case of floods seen in regions of Gunma Prefecture, being a wooden tower building of two stories erected on an elevated earth; the first floor stored miso (soybean paste) and other food and temporarily stored household goods, whereas, the second floor was used as a living quarter.
sen.cmt: 「訳漏れ」あり。補填し、文全体の構成を見直しました。
sen.e: - The mizu-zuka was a shelter in a case of floods seen in regions of Gunma Prefecture, being a wooden tower building of two stories erected on an elevated earth; the first floor stored miso (soybean paste) and other food and temporarily stored household goods, whereas, the second floor was used as a living quarter.

sen.j: その他にも堤防を利用した物や、必ずしも盛り土の上にない物など様々な形態がある。
sen.e: There are additional mounds that come in a variety of shapes including those built on dikes and the ones that were not erected over the elevated earth.
There are additional mounds that come in a variety of shapes including those built on dikes and the ones that were not erected on the elevated earth.
sen.cmt: erected over を ｅｒｅｃｔｅｄ on に変更。
sen.e: There are additional mounds that come in a variety of shapes including those built on dikes and the ones that were not erected on the elevated earth.

sen.j: 生物活動
sen.e: Biological Activity-Related Mounds
Biological Activity
sen.cmt: 原文に忠実な表現とした。
sen.e: Biological Activity

sen.j: 土竜塚（モグラ塚）
sen.e: Mogura Zuka (Molehills)
Mogura Zuka (Molehills)
Mogura Zuka (Molehills)

sen.j: - モグラ塚とはモグラの生活活動の跡であり地中から時々地面の近くに出てきたときに土が盛り上がった場所をさす。
sen.e: - A molehill means a pile of dirt created when a mole comes out of ground being a sign of biological activities of that creature.
- A molehill means a pile of dirt created when a mole comes out of ground being a sign of biological activities of that creature.
- A molehill means a pile of dirt created when a mole comes out of ground being a sign of biological activities of that creature.

sen.j: 蟻塚（アリ塚）
sen.e: Ari Zuka (Anthills)
Ari Zuka (Anthills)
Ari Zuka (Anthills)

sen.j: - 蟻塚とはシロアリが巣を作るために体液と土や植物を混ぜて作った搭状の山
sen.e: - An anthill is a tower-shape mound made by termites using their bodily fluid, earth and plants for their nest.
- An anthill is a tower-shape mound made by termites using their bodily fluid, earth and plants for their nest.
- An anthill is a tower-shape mound made by termites using their bodily fluid, earth and plants for their nest.

sen.j: 糞塚（フン塚）
sen.e: Funzuka (Dung Piles)
Funzuka (Dung Piles)
Funzuka (Dung Piles)

sen.j: - 糞塚とはタヌキなどの動物がマーキングや習性として決まった場所に糞をしたために山状になった場所。
sen.e: - A funzuka is a pile of feces of animals such as Japanese raccoons as they have a habit of defecating at the same place to mark their territories.
- The funzuka is a pile of feces of animals such as Japanese raccoons, being made because these animals have a habit of defecating at the same place to mark their territories.
- The funzuka is a pile of feces of animals such as Japanese raccoons, being made because these animals have a habit of defecating at the same place to mark their territories.
